definition[0]: to involve something as a necessary part or result
example[0]: A new computer system entails a lot of re-training.
example[1]: Some foreign travel is entailed in the job.
example[2]: The journey will entail changing trains twice.
definition[1]: if you entail property, you arrange for it to be given to a specific person, usually your oldest son, when you die
definition[2]: when ownership of land and property can only pass to a certain person, especially the oldest son, when the owner dies
example[3]: Until the eighteenth century aristocratic landed property was generally governed by entail, which worked to secure large estates.
